quiz.title: Unit 7: Labor Markets (Quiz 28)
quiz.subtitle: 7.4 The Labor Supply Curve: Graphical Labor Supply (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Labor Supply Curve, Work-Leisure Choice, Backward-Bending Supply, Market Supply

questions.question: The labor supply curve typically shows the relationship between:
options: Wage rate and quantity of labor demanded
Wage rate and quantity of labor supplied
questions.explanation: The labor supply curve graphs the wage rate (vertical axis) against the quantity of labor workers are willing to supply (horizontal axis).

questions.question: For an individual worker, the labor supply curve is based on the:
questions.explanation: Individual labor supply decisions involve trading off work (income) against leisure time, with the wage rate representing the price of leisure.

questions.question: The substitution effect of a wage increase causes workers to:
questions.explanation: The substitution effect makes leisure more expensive (higher opportunity cost), encouraging workers to substitute work for leisure.

questions.question: The income effect of a wage increase causes workers to:
questions.explanation: The income effect makes workers feel richer with the same hours worked, increasing demand for normal goods including leisure, thus reducing work hours.

questions.question: A backward-bending labor supply curve occurs when:
options: The income effect dominates at high wage levels
questions.explanation: At high wage levels, the income effect (desire for more leisure) can overcome the substitution effect (incentive to work more), causing the curve to bend backward.

questions.question: On a standard labor supply graph, the vertical axis represents:
questions.explanation: The vertical axis shows the wage rate (price of labor), while the horizontal axis shows the quantity of labor supplied.

questions.question: The market labor supply curve is derived by:
options: Summing individual labor supply curves horizontally
questions.explanation: At each wage rate, sum the quantities of labor supplied by all individual workers to get the market labor supply curve.

questions.question: A rightward shift in the labor supply curve could be caused by:
options: An increase in the wage rate
questions.explanation: Immigration increases the number of workers willing to work at each wage rate, shifting the supply curve rightward.

questions.question: The reservation wage is:
options: The minimum wage set by government
The lowest wage at which a worker will accept employment
The average wage in an industry
The wage paid to reserve workers
questions.explanation: The reservation wage is the minimum wage that would induce a person to enter the labor force or accept a particular job.

questions.question: On an individual labor supply graph, the area above the supply curve and below the wage rate represents:
questions.explanation: This area represents the difference between what workers receive and their reservation wages - their economic surplus from working.

questions.question: An increase in non-labor income (such as inheritance) would cause the labor supply curve to:
questions.explanation: Higher non-labor income increases the demand for leisure, reducing labor supply at each wage rate and shifting the curve leftward.

questions.question: The substitution effect is strongest for:
questions.explanation: Low-wage workers are more responsive to wage changes because they have stronger incentives to increase work hours to raise their standard of living.

questions.question: A movement along the labor supply curve occurs when:
questions.explanation: Changes in the wage rate cause movement along the supply curve, while other factors cause shifts of the entire curve.

questions.question: The labor force participation rate affects the labor supply curve by:
options: Determining the slope of the demand curve
Influencing the number of people willing to work
questions.explanation: Higher labor force participation means more people are willing to work at each wage rate, shifting the supply curve rightward.

questions.question: On a backward-bending labor supply curve, the upward-sloping portion indicates:
questions.explanation: The upward-sloping portion occurs at lower wage levels where the substitution effect (work more when wages rise) dominates the income effect.

questions.question: Changes in social norms regarding women working would affect labor supply by:
options: Causing movement along the supply curve
questions.explanation: Social norms affect people's willingness to work at given wage rates, shifting the entire labor supply curve.

questions.question: The elasticity of labor supply measures:
options: How responsive quantity supplied is to wage changes
How fast wages increase over time
The slope of the labor demand curve
questions.explanation: Labor supply elasticity = % change in quantity supplied รท % change in wage. It indicates how sensitive workers are to wage changes.

questions.question: A perfectly inelastic labor supply curve would be:
questions.explanation: A vertical supply curve means quantity supplied does not change when the wage changes - perfectly inelastic supply.

questions.question: An increase in income tax rates would likely cause the labor supply curve to:
questions.explanation: Higher income taxes reduce the net wage, making work less attractive and reducing labor supply at each gross wage rate.

questions.question: The market labor supply curve for a specific occupation is generally:
options: More elastic than individual supply curves
Less elastic than individual supply curves
questions.explanation: Market supply is more elastic because workers can move between occupations in response to wage differences, while individuals face more constraints.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand labor supply curves, the work-leisure tradeoff, and factors affecting labor supply.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics but should review the substitution and income effects, and how to interpret labor supply graphs.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: the work-leisure choice, substitution vs. income effects, and factors that shift vs. move along the supply curve.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that labor supply involves trading off work (income) against leisure, and workers respond to both substitution and income effects of wage changes.
